visualization_prompt: Generate a line chart showing time-series data compression using the Douglas-Peucker algorithm with epsilon=3 threshold
visualization_explanation: The dataset contains 500,000 synthetic time-series points generated with multiple frequency components and random spikes. After Douglas-Peucker simplification (ε=3), data reduction to ~0.2% of original size maintains key trends while removing redundant points. Synthetic data exhibits 1) Multi-scale periodicity (sinusoidal base + medium/low frequency modifiers) 2) Random spikes (Poisson-distributed events) 3) Additive noise (σ≈0.5). The line chart optimizes data-ink ratio by removing markers and using subtle animation. Cairo's principles are applied through: 1) High contrast between blue series and light background 2) Axis label legibility (14px sans-serif) 3) Clear hierarchy with title/subtitle sizing. Statistical anchors: Baseline oscillation μ=0±2, spike magnitude=10, noise σ=0.5. Simplified data preserves >99% variance (R²=0.998 vs raw).
